qas.question: What was the first federal law that regulated wildlife commerce?
What did the first federal wildlife commerce law prohibit?

answers.text: interstate commerce of animals killed in violation of state game laws

qas.question: What wildlife was covered by the first federal wildlife commerce regulation?

answers.text: all fish and wildlife and their parts or products, as well as plants

qas.question: What law passed in 1940 regarding the population of the U.S. national bird?
What was the first federal treaty?

plausible_answers.text: animals killed in violation of state game laws

qas.question: What did the first federal law on wildlife allow regarding interstate commerce?
What was the name of the 1937 treaty?

context: <b4_0>The <a0_0>Lacey Act<b4_0/> of 1900<a0_0/> was the first federal law that regulated commercial animal markets. It prohibited <a1_0>interstate commerce of <b6_0>animals killed in violation of state game laws<b6_0/><a1_0/>, and covered <a2_0>all fish and wildlife and their parts or products, as well as plants<a2_0/>. Other legislation followed, including <b5_0>the Migratory Bird Conservation Act<b5_0/> of 1929, a 1937 treaty prohibiting the hunting of right and gray whales, and the <a3_0><b7_0>Bald Eagle Protection Act<b7_0/> of 1940<a3_0/>. These <b8_0>later laws<b8_0/> had a low cost to society–the species were relatively rare–and little opposition was raised.
